Cu6Se4.5 Nanoparticles from a single source precursor: Recyclable and efficient catalyst for cross-dehydrogenative coupling of tertiary amines with terminal alkynes Sonu Gupta Hemant Joshi Nidhi Jain ⁎ Ajai K. Singh ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi 110016, India Department of Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology Delhi New Delhi 110016 India ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Cu6Se4.5 NPs, synthesized for the first time from a SSP are efficient and reusable catalyst for synthesis of propargylamines under solvent-free conditions. The use of copper selenide nanocatalyst for an efficient and regioselective cross-dehydrogenative coupling (CDC) of tertiary amines with terminal alkynes in the presence of tert-butyl hydroperoxide as the oxidant is demonstrated for the first time. The catalyst comprising of unique Cu6Se4.5 nanoparticles synthesized from a single source precursor CuSePh, is required in much lower amount (1mol%), and is recyclable up to four reaction cycles with slight loss in activity. The reaction can be executed in the absence of solvent, is applicable to aromatic, benzylic, and aliphatic tertiary amines, and furnishes propargylamines in moderate to good yields. Keywords Nanocatalysis Copper selenide Single-source precursor Cross-dehydrogenative coupling Propargylamines 1 Introduction Cross Dehydrogenative Coupling (CDC) has emerged as a powerful tool in modern organic synthesis for the construction of carbon–carbon and carbon-heteroatom bonds in an atom economic and efficient manner [1]. The oxidative coupling of two different CH bonds catalyzed by transition metals provides an access to a diverse array of aromatic and heterocyclic molecules without the need for their pre-functionalization [2]. CDC has been successfully demonstrated for a variety of alkylation, alkynylation, allylation, and arylation reactions [3]. Synthesis of propargylamines and their derivatives via CDC between amines and alkynes is an attractive route [4], and has been accomplished using copper [3a,5] iron [6] and silver [7] catalysts. This approach has significant advantages over the traditional methods for propargylamine synthesis such as nucleophilic alkynylation of functionalized amines, or transition metal catalysed addition of alkynes to imines [8] since they require the presence of a leaving group or the use of imines derived from pre-functionalized aldehydes and amines. While CDC route for propargylamine synthesis offers several merits, the reaction requires large quantity of catalyst resulting in generation of vast amount of waste. Also, their scope of amine coupling partners is typically favorable for aryl amines [3a,4a,9] and tetrahydroisoquinoline derivatives [3a,4a,10] while CDC with the rather unreactive aliphatic tertiary amines has limited reports [4a–c]. These limitations challenge and demand the development of more efficient, economical and generalized routes for propargylamines as they are synthetically valuable intermediates for many biologically active compounds such as lactams [11], oxotremorine analogues [12], conformationally restricted peptides [13], and isosteres [14]. To enhance the efficiency of CDC, nanocatalysis offers a promising approach. In nanophase, the catalyst possesses high surface to volume ratio, has more catalytically active sites, and maintains the intrinsic features of a heterogeneous catalyst thus improving the overall efficiency of the system [15–17]. Although extensive efforts have been directed towards CuNP assisted reduction [18a] cross-couplings [18b–f], and other reactions, [18g–j] there are very few reports on CuNP mediated CH bond activations [5g,19]. In our efforts directed towards developing synthetically useful strategies using copper [20], we explored the synthesis of propargylamines via CDC using copper nanocatalyst. Cu selenide NPs were synthesized through a single source precursor (SSP) route, since this approach permits an intrinsic control on reactivity and stoichiometry, and is free from issues related to air and moisture instability of the precursor [21]. We have previously reported the synthesis of Cu2Se nanoflakes using selenated propylamine as Se source, and used them for catalyzing Suzuki and Sonogashira reactions [22]. In the present work, we disclose for the first time the synthesis of Cu6Se4.5NPs using SSP route, and their application in oxidative CDC of terminal alkynes and tertiary amines under solvent free conditions. 2 Results and discussion The Cu6Se4.5NPs (Scheme 1 ) were prepared by thermolysis of CuSePh, synthesized by modifying the reported procedure for synthesis of CuSPh23 and characterized using 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectroscopy (see spectrum 1 and 2 in Supporting information). The NPs were authenticated by PXRD, SEM-EDX, and HRTEM data. PXRD pattern of Cu6Se4.5NPs exhibited diffraction lines (hkl) at 101, 110, 021, and 024 (Fig. 1 ). These diffraction peaks were indexed to the hexagonal phase of Cu6Se4.5NPs, as they showed good agreement with the literature data (JCPDS 72-2130). TEM images revealed the particles to have spherical morphology with a size of ∼5–7nm (Fig. S1, Supporting information). SEM-energy-dispersive X-ray spectral data confirmed the presence of Cu and Se in these NPs in the ratio 6:4.5 (Fig. S2, Supporting information). The oxidation states of Cu and Se in Cu6Se4.5 NPs have been assigned with the help of XPS analysis. As shown in Fig. 2 , the sample consists of copper and selenium only. The Cu 2p spectrum illustrates that the peaks for binding energies for Cu 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 appearing at 931.5 and 951.5eV respectively are symmetric, narrow, and devoid of satellite. These values of binding energies indicate the oxidation state of Cu in Cu6Se4.5 NPs to be (+1) (Fig. 2a), in accordance with a recent literature report [24a]. In the Se 3d XPS spectrum (Fig. 2b), the binding energy peak corresponding to 53.85eV is characteristic of Se−2 [23b]. Cross-dehydrogenative coupling between model substrates N,N-dimethylbenzylamine (1a) and phenylacetylene (2a) was initiated using tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), and Cu6Se4.5NPs as the catalyst. We were pleased to see that the synthesized NPs were effective in catalyzing the reaction, and yielded the desired product Benzyl-methyl-(3-phenyl-prop-2-ynyl)-amine (3a) in 62% yield (Table 1 , entry 1). Encouraged with the finding, we next optimized the reaction conditions by varying the solvent, time, and catalyst loading. It was found that addition of solvents such as water, DMSO, DCE, toluene, and dioxane to the reaction mixture containing equivalent amounts of 1a and 2a, Cu6Se4.5NPs, and TBHP resulted in a significant drop in the yield of 3a (Table 1, entries 2–6). Since the reaction gave the highest product yield under neat conditions (Table 1, entry 1), it was decided to carry out further studies in the absence of added solvent. Lowering the catalyst loading to 0.5mol% decreased the yield of 3a to 19% (Table 1, entry 7). It was also found that the reaction did not proceed in the absence of copper catalyst or TBHP (Table 1, entry 8 and 9). Use of NBS as the oxidant did not help the reaction either, and the yield of 3a decreased to only 7% (Table 1, entry 10). With other oxidants such as benzoquinone and K2S2O8, 3a was not formed at all (Table 1, entries 11 and 12). Further, reducing the reaction time to 2h resulted in a lower conversion to product, while increasing it up to 10h did not alter the product yield (entries 13 and 14, Table 1). Furthermore, lowering the reaction temperature to 70°C or increasing the amount of TBHP to 0.4mL also led to decreased product yields (entries 15 and 16, Table 1). It was also seen that increasing the amount of 1a to 1.5 and 2.0 equivalents, reduced the yield of 3a to 58 and 53% respectively (entries 17 and 18, Table 1). Notably, the reaction was carried out under nitrogen atmosphere, since the presence of air converted 1a into benzaldehyde, and the desired coupled product was not formed at all. Further, using 1mol% of the precursor CuSePh as the catalyst reduced the yield of 3a to 48% emphasizing the positive influence of NPs on the reaction. With the best optimized conditions (Table 1, entry 1) involving equivalent amounts of substrates, 1mol% Cu6Se4.5NPs, and 1.5mmol of TBHP in water at 100°C for 3h, we next determined the scope of the reaction. It is worth mentioning that the use of nanocatalyst resulted in a five-fold reduction in the catalytic loading, and showed a marked increment in the yield of 3a from 36% reported with 5mol% CuBr [4a] to 62% with only 1mol% of the prepared Cu6Se4.5 NPs. These conditions are in fact also superior to the previous report using 20mol% CuBr and 1.0 equivalent NBS to yield 52% of 3a from 1a and 2a as substrates [4c]. A variety of N,N-dimethylbenzyl amines (1) and terminal alkynes (2) were subjected to CDC under the optimized conditions, and moderate to good yields of the corresponding propargylamines (3) were obtained (Table 2 ). It was found that for both benzyl amines and aryl alkynes, the substrates containing electron-donating groups, in general, gave higher yield of the corresponding propargylamines (3b–3c, 3m–3o, Table 2). The presence of electron-withdrawing chloro- group at ortho, meta and para position on N,N-dimethylbenzylamine did not affect the reaction significantly, and similar yield of the products was obtained (3d–3j, Table 2). With bulkier bromo group, and strongly electron withdrawing nitro group at para-position, the yield of products 3k and 3l dropped to 58 and 52% respectively. It may be noted that in unsymmetrical tertiary aliphatic amine with three different alkyl groups on nitrogen atom, alkynylation occurred selectively at the N-methyl group most likely due to steric considerations (3q, Table 2) [4c]. The reaction was also feasible with aliphatic alkyne as the coupling partner, and gave the desired product 3r, albeit in lower yield. Heterocyclic alkyne derivative was also tested, and successfully underwent CDC to yield 3s in 41% yield (Fig. 3 ). The reaction was also explored with an arylamine and the results are summarized in Table 3 . N,N-dimethylaniline (4) on reaction with various aryl alkynes gave the desired products 5a–5c in high yields (72–77%). Coupling with heterocyclic 2-alkynylpyridine, however, gave the desired product, 5d in 43% yield. To quantitate the activity of the NPs, turnover frequencies (TOFs) for the model reaction between 1a and 2a were calculated both with Cu6Se4.5 NPs, as well as with CuBr as the catalyst. It was found that the reaction catalyzed by NPs gave 8 fold higher TOF than the corresponding CuBr catalyzed reaction. This represented a significant improvement over the earlier reports [4]. Further, the recyclability of the catalyst was also established. After extracting the organic contents in chloroform, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation. CDC was iteratively repeated with the same batch of the catalyst, and up to four recycles, a minimal reduction in the yield was seen with no signs of catalyst deactivation (Fig. 4 ). HR-TEM images of the catalyst recovered after fourth reaction cycle showed that Cu6Se4.5NPs agglomerated to some extent which might be responsible for a lower conversion {Fig. 3(b)}. Moreover, ICP-MS analysis of the reaction concentrate after the first batch of reaction also indicated some leaching out of the catalyst, showing a concentration of 2.18mg/g and 1.93mg/g for copper and selenium respectively (S3, Supporting information). Next, to ascertain the involvement of free radical species in the reaction; quenching studies with TEMPO were carried out. We found that on addition of TEMPO to the reaction mixture, the reaction did not take place at all, and the starting substrate 1a was recovered as such. Consistent with the radical mechanism, addition of radical scavenger such as ascorbic acid was found to reduce the product yield in a dose-dependent manner (Table 4 ). Based on these observations, a plausible mechanism for the reaction is proposed in Scheme 2 . In the first step, activation of terminal alkyne by Cu6Se4.5NPs results in the formation of copper(I) acetylide intermediate A. In a parallel step, reaction of the tertiary amine with TBHP produces radical cation B [3a,4c,5g]. The formation of radical cation B is supported by the electronic influence witnessed in the product yields of reactions wherein the amine possessed +R groups at the para- position. Higher yields were obtained by virtue of stabilization of positive charge on radical cation intermediate. This is followed by abstraction of hydrogen free radical from B to give the iminium ion intermediate, which on combination with copper forms C. Eventually, coupling of these two intermediates A and C results in the formation of the desired product 3, along with regeneration of the copper catalyst. [4a] The presence of selenium in the NP catalyst helps in stabilizing intermediates A and C by increasing electron density on copper, and rendering it electron rich. The PXRD of Cu6Se4.5 NPs recovered after the first reaction cycle, showed the catalyst to be intact (S4, Supporting Information). The relatively higher intensity of peaks in the recovered catalyst compared to the parent catalyst, however, indicated some extent of agglomeration of NPs during catalysis process. 3 Conclusions In summary, we demonstrate the synthesis of Cu6Se4.5 NPs for the first time from a single source precursor, CuSePh. The NPs are uniformly distributed with a particle size of 5–7nm, and serve as efficient and reusable catalyst for CDC of aliphatic, benzylic, and aromatic tertiary amines with terminal alkynes under solvent-free conditions. The protocol is the first instance where a copper selenide based nano-catalytic system has been employed for dual sp3 CH and sp CH bond activation. The reaction is simple and economical, and gives moderate to good yield of propargylamines with alkynylation occurring selectively at the methyl of tertiary amines. Reduction in particle size of catalyst leads to an enhanced catalytic activity with higher product yields compared to previous reports employing commercially available bulk copper, even at reduced catalytic loading of 1mol%. The protocol offers broad substrate scope along with catalyst reusability up to four reaction cycles. 4 Experimental section 4.1 Physical measurement 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Spectrospin DPX 300 NMR spectrometer at 300.13 and 75.47MHz respectively. The chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to the internal standard (tetramethylsilane in case of 1H, and 13C{1H} NMR). All reactions were carried out in glassware dried in an oven. For scanning electron microscope (SEM) studies, Carl ZEISS EVO5O instrument was used. Sample was mounted on a circular metallic sample holder with a sticky carbon tape. The associated EDX system Model QuanTax 200, based on the SDD technology and giving an energy resolution of 127eV at MnKα was used for estimating elemental compositions. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies were carried out on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using Ni-filtered CuKα radiation, scan speed of 1s and scan step of 0.05o. Transmission electron microscopic (TEM) studies were carried out using a JEOL JEM200CX TEM instrument operated at 200kV. The specimens for these studies were prepared by dispersing the powdered sample in ethanol by ultrasonic treatment. Few drops of resulting solution were put on a porous carbon film supported on a copper grid and dried in air. The XPS studies were performed with a specs instrument equipped with a Al-Kα radiation source (E =1486.6eV), and a hemispherical analyzer. ICP-MS analysis was done on Agilent ICPMS7900. 4.2 Chemicals and reagents Trioctylphosphine (TOP), CuSO4·5H2O, diphenyldiselenide, and sodium borohydride were procured from Sigma-Aldrich (USA), and were used as received. Hydroxylamine hydrochloride (NH2OH·HCl) and N,N-dimethylbenzylamine (Acros organics), Phenylacetylene and ammonia (Spectrochem) were used as received. All the solvents of AR grade i.e. acetone, diethylether, and ethanol were dried and distilled before use by known standard procedures [25]. 4.3 Synthesis of CuSePh To an ice cold mixture of conc. aqueous NH3 (10mL) and water (40mL), CuSO4·5H2O (0.4994g, 2mmol) was added followed by addition of NH2OH·HCl (0.3099g, 4.46mmol). The contents were stirred overnight at 25°C under nitrogen. In a separate three neck 100mL round bottom flask, diphenyldiselenide (0.3121g, 1.0mmol) dissolved in 40mL of ethanol was heated at 80°C. Sodium borohydride (0.07566g, 2.0mmol) was added to the solution of diphenyldiselenide which became colourless due to the formation of PhSe−Na+. The solution of [Cu(NH3)2]+ was added dropwise to this colourless solution with constant stirring resulting in formation of an orange colored solid. The solid product was collected via filtration, washed several times with water, ethanol and ether respectively and dried in vacuum. Orange solid (0.17g, Yield: 76%). 1H NMR (300MHz, DMSO); δ7.61 (br, 2H), 7.31(br, 3H). 13C NMR (75.0MHz); 130.8, 129.9, 129.4, 127.8. 4.4 Synthesis of Cu6Se4.5 NPs In a three necked flask (100mL), a slurry containing 0.5mmol of CuSePh in 4mL trioctylphosphine (TOP) was heated to 100°C to remove water and oxygen. The resulting homogeneous brown solution was heated to 220°C under N2 and kept at the same temperature for 90min, affording a dark colloidal solution. The solution was cooled and Cu6Se4.5NPs were formed on addition of excess acetone. They were washed with acetone by centrifugation and dried in vacuo under desiccator. 4.5 General procedure for CDC reaction To a mixture of N,N-dimethylbenzylamine (0.1352g, 1.0mmol), phenylacetylene (0.1022g, 1.0mmol) and aqueous tert-butyl hydroperoxide (70% wt/v) (0.2mL, 1.5mmol),Cu6Se4.5NPs (1mol%, 1.3mg) were added under nitrogen at room temperature. The reaction temperature was raised to 100°C and the contents were stirred at the same temperature for 3h. The reaction mixture was then cooled to room temperature. The resulting suspension was diluted with diethyl ether and the organic layer was washed off with water (3×50mL) and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. coredata.dc:description: The use of copper selenide nanocatalyst for an efficient and regioselective cross-dehydrogenative coupling (CDC) of tertiary amines with terminal alkynes in the presence of tert-butyl hydroperoxide as the oxidant is demonstrated for the first time. The catalyst comprising of unique Cu6Se4.5 nanoparticles synthesized from a single source precursor CuSePh, is required in much lower amount (1mol%), and is recyclable up to four reaction cycles with slight loss in activity. The reaction can be executed in the absence of solvent, is applicable to aromatic, benzylic, and aliphatic tertiary amines, and furnishes propargylamines in moderate to good yields.
coredata.dc:title: Cu6Se4.5 Nanoparticles from a single source precursor: Recyclable and efficient catalyst for cross-dehydrogenative coupling of tertiary amines with terminal alkynes
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
